Overall, the book was informative and educational. The larger message, I felt, was two-fold. One, that humans are predisposed biologically to favor family ties. Two, that the state, the elite and the middle class in a careful balance form the basis of every political system. With the backdrop of accounts of the various prominent successful and unsuccessful states and groups of people starting from tribes from what is present-day Germany, China, Mongols, Russians and Ottomons, this was very convincing. It appears that for the majority of "failed states", the reason boiled down either to not being able to curtail the family biases of the public OR failing to keep one of the three (state, elites, middle class) from becoming too powerful and destroying the balance. I picked up on a few brand new learnings about concepts and elements of history like Janesaries, Brahmins, Confucianism vs Legalism and the vastly varied roles of religion in the different Western European states that I was fascinated to learn about for the first time ever. There were a few times when I lost interest in the details -- making this not a very easy read all the time but in the end, this was a worthwhile time investment.

The Origins of Political Order is a massive and very insightful book. It provides a comprehensive historical analysis that goes from the beginning of the concept of state to the creation of liberal democracies.The treatise is very detailed and effective also thanks to the historical parallels that are presents in the whole book. These really help in making the arguments exposed very strong.As example I really liked the parallel between the creation of the state in China, India and in ancient Rome or the parallel between the French and the British societies in the centuries that drove to the french revolution.Most of the book revolves around the concepts of the role of the state of law, government accountability and state building as building blocks for the construction of a liberal democracy. These concept are eviscerated in details without becoming repetitive. This adds a lot of value to the book itself.Special mention is deserved by the notes on the causes of political decay. I specifically liked the point made by the author about the misalignment between present needs and institutions as a cause of decay. It is a very powerful message delivered with strong arguments.

The Origins of Political Order is an ambitious effort that covers over two millennia of human political development across dozens of nations. Fukuyama spares the reader neither detail nor idiosyncratic fact in his search for the basis of political power and stability. He begins his book with discussions of kin and tribal level societies and the lessons we can gather from their development. Rather than existing as individuals in nature (as promoted by Locke), humans have always been social creatures that lived in groups and the concepts of ownership and property was usually shared on a communal level. Then, Fukuyama dives into a series of case studies: China, India, the Middle East, and Europe (which he then breaks up even more into studies of Spain, France, Hungary, Russia, and England) to compare the ways different states came into existence. Finally, he ends his book with a broader discussion of the necessary elements for political stability (a strong state, rule of law, and accountability) and how there are multiple paths to such an endstate. Overall, the case studies can be a bit in the weeds and boring at times, but Fukuyama's strength is in connecting the dots at the end and bringing his argument home. Even if you just skim through the case studies and focus on the beginning and ending sections of the book, you will be well served. My greatest takeaway was that political order necessitates BALANCE between the stakeholders at play and that the foundational pillars of American democracy are great not because they are the only path to successful state building and economic growth (see China), but because they provide guide rails to prevent our system from veering off course because of one bad leader. Yet, our own government's stability and legitimacy is built off its ability to successfully combat the crises of our time, and if it unable to adapt it will inevitably lead to ruin from either within (see French Revolution) or without (see Rome). Looking forward, policy makers should recognize that our own position of strength is not a function of deterministic history but a response to generations of leaders who made wise choices and led boldly when the time came, and that our future success is dependent on their ability to do the same. I look forward to reading Fukuyama's second volume.

description: Virtually all human societies were once organized tribally, yet over time most developed new political institutions which included a central state that could keep the peace and uniform laws that applied to all citizens. Some went on to create governments that were accountable to their constituents. We take these institutions for granted, but they are absent or are unable to perform in many of today’s developing countries—with often disastrous consequences for the rest of the world.Francis Fukuyama, author of the bestselling The End of History and the Last Man and one of our most important political thinkers, provides a sweeping account of how today’s basic political institutions developed. The first of a major two-volume work, The Origins of Political Order begins with politics among our primate ancestors and follows the story through the emergence of tribal societies, the growth of the first modern state in China, the beginning of the rule of law in India and the Middle East, and the development of political accountability in Europe up until the eve of the French Revolution.Drawing on a vast body of knowledge—history, evolutionary biology, archaeology, and economics—Fukuyama has produced a brilliant, provocative work that offers fresh insights on the origins of democratic societies and raises essential questions about the nature of politics and its discontents.
title:
The Origins of Political Order: From Prehuman Times to the French Revolution
      
          (Political Order)
